nodes.bodyText: nit: objectMapper might be more descriptive
I would say in this context from is a better description of that this variable represents.
Does this need to be a {@link List} of {@link FileEntriesLayer}?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -47,8 +47,8 @@
    * @return a {@link List} of {@link LayerObject} to use as part of a buildplan

nodes.bodyText: It can be, it doesn't really need to be exposed outside of this package though. Since this isn't a library it doesn't matter all that much. But it really should only be used for conversion within the package.

have we considered using Truth (https://truth.dev/) for our assertions? It could offer clearer error messaging and help in understanding the actual vs expected values --> assertThat(actual).isEqualTo(expected) (for example, the actual is always on the left-hand side in Truth so we don't need to remember the correct parameter ordering)
No we have not, but this seems like a good idea. We can add this in a new PR and then start writing new tests using Truth. We can also update old tests slowly to use it.
I realized, these values "os.version", "os.features", "variant", "features" are all ignored in the current implementation, because we don't support it at the jib-core level.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,58 @@
+# this buildfile doesn't necessarily work, just useful for testing parsing and translation
+apiVersion: jib/v1alpha1
+kind: BuildFile
+
+# "FROM" with detail for manifest lists or multiple architectures
+from:
+  image: "ubuntu"
+  # optional: if missing, then defaults to `linux/amd64`
+  platforms:
+    - architecture: "arm"
+      os: "linux"
+      os.version: "a"

nodes.bodyText: Close the reader with a try-resource block?
setName() probably unnecessary if it's only to get entries via getEntries().
oh right, must've been leftover from when I was trying to compare FileEntriesLayer objects directly
quick question on this: Is this test only for when a scratch base image is used? And is that why we allow some of these required parameters to be empty or null?

This test adds in only the required properties and then verifies that the output is the "defaults". When the defaults change, this will fail and we will know that we either have to revert the change or update our documentation to correctly reflect what the defaults are.
